Honestly, it's like American's aren't native speakers of English.

It's because 90+% of people don't become addicts and can handle recreational drugs but our government have run smear campaigns that make it seem like you do one hit and you become a crack whore who would sell their own mother for a hit.
Just look at alcohol, it's one of the most addictives freely available drugs that we have but only 7.2% of people are alcohol dependent (AUD). And even then, the criteria to make that percent is pretty easy/gov are boosting the stat numbers to scare us [(selecting just 2 out of 11 criteria gets you on the list)](https://www.niaaa.nih.gov/alcohol-health/overview-alcohol-consumption/alcohol-use-disorders) People with severe alcohol dependance (i.e. what most people consider alcoholics) are 1% of the population.
It's as others have mentioned in here. People don't get addicted to something because it's a drug; most people get addicted because they have a shitty life and the drug is an escape.

I dunno about that, I'm a Londoner and I can't stand the cold, honestly I'm terrible with it.
But I have indigenous family in the UAE and when I visit them I'm much better in the heat than they are. I walk around and have even done 3 hour runs in peak summer heat and I'm completely fine.
You couldn't pay me enough to go for a run on a cold london winters day (I train inside for winter).

I've always hated a 9-5 because when I've had jobs that don't require me to be in a certain times that my natural body clock works in fact on 30 hour cycles. So I'll sleep for 8 hours then be happily awake for 22 hours.
Honestly it's a constant struggle to fit into 24 hour days. I've resorted to not sleeping on Saturday nigts so that on Sundays I can go to bed, sleep for 8 hours and start my 9-5 like 'normal' people. Honestly come friday morning I'm exhausted from the horrible weekday body clock adjustment.
At school and univeristy I used to do all nighters on Tuesdays and Thursdays and that wasn't too bad because my classes were set in stone but with work you often have to go in early/work late so I had to change it to just Saturday and it's been tougher to adjust to.
And why am I yawning too.

I studied both in England (Kent) and in Madrid (Universidad Autnoma de Madrid).
Both Autnoma Kent are top ranked universities.
Kent was fantastic in every way; Madrid however was godawful.
The way I always describe it is, if you imagine a typical movie where a teacher goes to a school that's atrocious and fixes everything by the end. Well Autnoma is that school but without ever getting fixed.
The courses weren't challenging and the 'essays' were a joke, I remember having to write an 'essay' on Fascism in half a page!
Want help from a teacher? Tough! Most have maybe a 1 hour window, once a week for you to see them but given that you have other classes you essentially can't go to see them, and most just ignore their e-mails if you tried to ask for help that way.
Classes weren't open discussions like at Kent, it was you sit and listen for an hour, with most professors just talking without any clear plan about what will be discussed in the class, often we'd be asked 'what was I talking about last time'.
The social life was rubbish, campus life wasn't really a thing. Whereas in the UK campus life is a big deal.
I had two final exam clashes and despite having worked and studied all year I was told to just pick one exam and not worry about the other. Their logic was that you didn't need to pass every module to graduate as they only count your top few subjects when grading you. They really couldn't see why I was angry about this.
We had wild cats walking and crapping in the classrooms and corridors.
The trouble with most Spaniards is that they haven't studied abroad, so they think that is normal but if you ask any that have studied both in the UK and Spain they will tell you how eye opening it was to study in the UK.
All the Spanish erasmus students that I knew at Kent didn't want to go back to their Spanish uni after as they realised how bad they were.
I'm happy to answer any questions you have because honestly if I could go back in time I wouldn't have gone to a Spanish uni and neither would my friends that did. We still joke about how bad it was.

When I was in primary school the maths was ridiculously easy so the teacher would send me and two others into an empty room and told us to work on two secondary school books that the school had. We finished them within a term (wasnt pretty easy tbh), we told our teacher when we finished and she just shrugged and said find something to do, so then wed use the time to mostly browse wikipedia and try to find the best trivia.
The headteacher walked in on us one day and had a massive go at us and suspended us for 3 days. When we went back we had to stay in the class during maths and do the ridiculously easy maths, honestly it was torture and a complete waste of my time.
